origin_of_ch_char_book: The people of the Shang Dynasty preferred the color white, which was understood as a very clean. They liked to keep their clothes and bodies clean also. (浴, yu=yü, bath) shows a man inside a big tub cleaning himself with water . The tub is similar to the tall pots used for the ceremonies. So we can assume that the ancient people washed themselves before the important ceremonies, especially for the gods.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The oracle bone inscriptions start from " people ", there is a water point beside them, and from the " dish " on the bottom, it looks like a person washing one's body in a basin. Bronze and Xiao Zhuan sound from " water " and " gu ". The original meaning is bathing. "Shuowen": "Bath, shower your body. From the water, the valley sound." "Guang Yun. Candle Rhyme: "Bath, bath." "Zhou Li. Heaven official. "The Palace Man": "The King's Bath." Zheng Xuan's note: "Bath, so self-cleaning." Means to provide the king to wash his hair and bath.

The oracle bone inscriptions are used as the original meaning, and "Compilation" 1824 is: "For bathing." That is for bathing. Xu Zhongshu suspects that " bath " is a ritual of sacrificial rites. You must take a bath before sacrificing. Also used as the place name "Collection" 13575; "Let the bed go to the bath." That is, order to go to the place before bed.

Bronze inscriptions are used as the original meaning, Meng Jiji Fou: "Meng Jiji chose her lucky gold and made her own bath." It means that Meng Jiji chose bronze and cast a foul for washing herself. From archaeological data, it is speculated that the people of Chu had a set of bronze ritual vessels for bathing. They used a tripod to boil water for heating, use a bath to fill water, and use mirrors to bathe. This shows that people at that time paid much attention to bathing. This may prove that "bathing" is an integral part of the sacrificial ritual. Before the formal sacrificial ritual, one must first bathe and cleanse oneself (see Hunan Provincial Museum "In-depth exploration of the copper bath with a pattern of pan-虺").

Qin bamboo slips are used as the original meaning, "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Slips. Japanese Book A Type" Jian 104zheng: "Don't take a bath in Mao." It means not to wash your hair and body in Mao. Qin bamboo slips use " bath " as " vulgar ", "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Slips. "The Way of the Officials" Jane 40: "Changing people's customs and bathing (customs), there is no worries." It means that if the people's (bad) customs are changed, (governance) will have no worries.

Han silk script is used as the original meaning, "Mawangdui silk script. 52 sick side ", line 49:" Bath Road head start, under the best body, four (limb) no moisten. "" How , "that is wet; means a bath should start from the head until the lower body, and limbs Don't get wet. Han silk script borrows " bath " as " gu ", "Mawangdui silk book. The 243rd line of Lao Zi Yi Ben: "For the world to bath (valley), Hengde is the foot." The handed down version of "Lao Zi" is "For the world valley". This sentence means that eternal virtue is enough to become a valley where the world lives.

Chu Zhushu also borrows " bath " as " gu ." "Shangbo Chu Zhushu. "Rong Chengshi" Jane 31: "Take [卫止] (𨇙) in the river bath (gu)." " 𨇙 " may mean trampling. It means trampling on the valley.

The word " bath " was later extended from bathing to meaning immersion. Lu Xun "Grave. "Cultural Partialism": "Long bathing culture gradually realizes the dignity of human beings."

In Cantonese, the word "bathing" is interpreted as bathing, but in ancient times, " mu " and " bath " were divided into two words. " Mu " means washing one's hair and " bath " means taking a bath. In addition to "bath", Cantonese also uses "bath" to mean bathing.
humanum_short_description_en: Synopsis: On the oracle bone inscriptions , it starts with " people ", and there are water points next to them, and when it comes from " pans ", it resembles the shape of people washing themselves in a basin. Bronze and Xiao Zhuan sound from " water " and " gu ". The original meaning is bathing.
humanum_full_description:
甲骨文上從「人」，人之旁有水點，下從「皿」，象人在盆中洗身之形。金文、小篆從「水」，「谷」聲。本義是洗澡。《說文》：「浴，洒身也。从水，谷聲。」《廣韻．燭韻》：「浴，洗浴。」《周禮．天官．宮人》：「共王之沐浴。」鄭玄注：「沐浴，所以自清潔。」意指供給王洗頭洗澡。

　　甲骨文用作本義，《合集》1824正：「于浴用。」即沐浴用，徐中舒懷疑「浴」是祭祀的儀式，祭祀前必先洗澡。又用作地名《合集》13575；「令寢往浴。」即命令寢前去浴這個地方。

　　金文用作本義，孟縢姬缶：「孟縢姬揀其吉金，自作浴缶。」意謂孟縢姬挑選了青銅，自己鑄造了一個洗身用的缶。從考古資料推測，楚人有一套沐浴的青銅禮器，用鼎燒水加溫，用浴缶裝水，用鑒沐浴，可見當時人重視沐浴。這可能證明「沐浴」是祭祀儀式的組成部分，進行正式祭祀前要先沐浴潔淨自身（參湖南省博物館〈蟠虺紋銅浴缶深入探索〉）。

　　秦簡用作本義，《睡虎地秦簡．日書甲種》簡104正：「毋以卯沐浴。」意指不要在卯日洗頭和洗身。秦簡以「浴」為「俗」，《睡虎地秦簡．為吏之道》簡40：「變民習浴（俗），既毋後憂。」意指改變百姓（惡劣的）習俗，（管治）就會無後顧之憂。

　　漢帛書用作本義，《馬王堆帛書．五十二病方》第49行：「浴之道頭上始，下盡身，四支（肢）毋濡。」「濡」即沾濕；意謂洗澡應該從頭部開始，直到下身，而四肢則不要沾濕。漢帛書假借「浴」為「谷」，《馬王堆帛書．老子乙本》第243行：「為天下浴（谷），恆德乃足。」傳世本《老子》作「為天下谷」。這句指成為天下生息的山谷，永恆的德行才足夠。

　　楚竹書亦借「浴」為「谷」。《上博楚竹書．容成氏》簡31：「以[衛止]（𨇙）於溪浴（谷）。」「𨇙」可能表示踐踏。意即踐踏溪谷。

　　「浴」字後來從洗澡引申為沉浸之義。魯迅《墳．文化偏至論》：「久浴文化，則漸悟人類之尊嚴。」

　　粵語以「沐浴」一詞解作洗澡，但在古時，「沐」和「浴」分作兩個詞，「沐」指洗頭，「浴」才是洗澡。除了「沐浴」，粵語還會以「沖涼」表示洗澡。

浴字的基本解释

浴
yù
洗身，洗澡：沐浴。浴室。浴场。浴缸。浴巾。浴血（全身浸于血中，形容战斗激烈）。

浴字的汉语字典释义

[①]［yù］
［《廣韻》余蜀切，入燭，以。］
(1)洗身，洗澡。
(2)沉浸；浸染。
(3)特指浸洗蚕子。
(4)鸟飞忽上忽下貌。
(5)通“谷”。参见“浴神”。

浴字的起名意思

：理解为洗澡、沐浴。比喻受润泽。也有沉浸，浸染之意，如浴身浴德。

Meaning Mnemonic
A tsunami hits a valley, filling it up with water. Lucky for you, you're a giant, so you just lay down in the valley and use it to bathe.
Sure, there's a lot of water in the valley, but you're big too. It's the perfect place for you to bathe... and good thing too, you're getting smelly.
Reading Mnemonic
You know what would make the bathing experience even better? If you had some egg yolks (よく) to eat. Just crack those yolks into the water you bathe in, and it'll cook to perfection. Yum!
Imagine cooking egg yolks in the same water you bathe in.
